Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: High performance polymers from biomass
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project addresses the need for obtaining sustainable sources of chemicals and fuels. This proposal aims to solve the problem in the context of a chemical with uses in high performance polymers with total addressable market in excess of $7 billion per year. A key requirement of such processes is high efficiency of conversion for economic viability. We propose an integrated bio-thermochemical platform for production of a monomer which can be used for production of unsaturated polyester resins. The polymer properties can be fine-tuned by copolymerizing our monomer with other monomers so as to achieve desired cost and performance needs.

The intellectual merit of this project is in the high yield bioprocess coupled with selective chemical conversion to develop an economically viable bio-based process for production of a bulk chemical. The proposed research would involve testing of various catalysts for polymerization of the monomer along with other co-monomers, followed by characterization of these polymer formulations. Another aspect of the work would be screening of downstream processing methods for producing monomer at desired specification. Upon full development, the process could produce a bulk chemical at half the current market price, and with renewable sources as the raw inputs. This would translate to lower cost to end customers and a 70% reduction in greenhouse gas footprint relative to existing petro-based process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aimed to develop a green technology to produce plastics and resins from biological sources. This new process would displace the traditional method of using petrochemical feedstock, which reduces greenhouse gas emission and improving the environment not only in displacing petrochemical use but also by sequestering atmospheric carbon in the polymer resins. The process would also be sustainable, cost competitive and demand responsible to end user in the polymer industry. Development of this process would boost US competitiveness in polymer industry by reducing reliance on foreign imports.

We successfully produced greater than 5 kg of a biochemical via fermentation from sugars and purified this chemical to >98% purity using a low cost scalable distillation process. While attempts to directly polymerize this compound into polymers via established chemical reactions prove unsuccessful, we were able to convert this intermediate to a variety of monomers – the building blocks for producing plastics and resins, using established industrial process at bench scale. We created a variety of polymers using these monomers and demonstrated that they have properties comparable to commercial resins and have filed a patent on the use of these bio-based monomers. Having successfully achieved our goal of producing polymers in the lab using our novel bio-based monomers, we are ready to scale up our production process to pilot scale with our most promising monomer with the goal of commercialization by 2020.  

 

 


Last Modified: 08/19/2016
Modified by: Brian Lee

Development of this process would boost US competitiveness in polymer industry by reducing reliance on foreign imports. We successfully produced greater than 5 kg of a biochemical via fermentation from sugars and purified this chemical to >98% purity using a low cost scalable distillation process. We created a variety of polymers using these monomers and demonstrated that they have properties comparable to commercial resins and have filed a patent on the use of these bio-based monomers.
